content:
I have four blocks in a region in the order: 1, 2, 3, 4. I'd like to display them as such: blocks.png but for the life of me I can't work out how...

CSS Flex doesn't seem to work as blocks 2 & 4 don't display next to block 3, but rather below it. CSS Grid also doesn't seem to work as I have to add each block into its own row/column and it seems hard to calculate. Float might work, but that seems a bit hacky, as does CSS Columns... Any suggestions?
I suspect Flex or Grid will work, I'm just doing something wrong.

The obvious solution (which I'm assuming that you have already thought of, but are not explicitly mentioning) would be to place blocks 1, 2, and 4 in a container div, and then render that div next to that of block 3. ...in other words, why not create a separate region for blocks 1, 2, and 4?
Yeah, I don't want to go changing layout templates, etc. in order to add extra markup.
Right :thinking:
The person I'd usually ask things like these was @wesruv :sweat_smile:
@BWPanda I'm assuming that you've also considered floating those blocks.

Yes, I mentioned above that float might work but I think it's hacky. I'd have to float block 3 to the right, the add a right-margin to the other blocks to stop them overflowing into the second column.
Right. Sorry, I missed that.
Just tried using a float, but then I'd have to change the source order...
And if I use position: absolute; for block 3 it overflows the container.
We have our own frontend guru at Salsa. I'll ask him for ideas, but it'll have to wait till tomorrow.
No worries, I'm off to bed now anyway :-) Thanks!
Sure @BWPanda ...sleep tight :zzz: :wave:

... and later on (tomorrow): good morning @BWPanda !

Definitely grid. (The css selectors are just placeholders)

.parentdiv {
display: grid;
grid-template-columns: [left] 50% [right] 50%;
}

.parentdiv > div {
grid-column: left;
}

.parentdiv .thirdblock {
grid-column: right;
grid-row-start: 1;
grid-row-end: 4;
}

Yes, it's possible to name areas using brackets like [left], I'm not sure how good the browser support is, though.

Thanks @indigoxela, that does what I need! Unfortunately I have a bug (which I think is what made me think CSS Grid wasn't working in the first place) wherein Block 1 is a views slideshow, and that row is really tall, as in, you need to scroll down a long way to see Block 2 below it. I suspect this has something to do with the slideshow (maybe the height of the row is based on all the stacked images before they're collapsed into a slideshow...)
Yep, if I hide or replace that particular slideshow block, all the others display as expected.
Ok, fixed. Adding align-items: start; did the trick.
@indigoxela ++
indigoxela leveled up! (Karma: 8)
I wasn't aware of that grid-template-columns syntax with the brackets! That's interesting, I would have done essentially the same thing, but I didn't know about brackets :joy:

Ok, now I'm back to this again because I just added another block (call it '2.5') which sits above block 3 in the right column. And using my current grid layout means that block 3 doesn't sit right below it, but rather sits in line with block 2 further down the page (since block 1 is quite tall compared to block 2.5...

Maybe better if I share an actual screenshot: image.png

These blocks are all in one region (main) on the page, in the following order (which I'd prefer to keep for when they're displayed on mobile):

  1. Slideshow
  2. About
  3. News
  4. Search
  5. Facebook
This is pretty much how I want it already, I'd just like the News block to sit right up under the Search block...

BWPanda said:

And using my current grid layout means that block 3 doesn't sit right below it, but rather sits in line with block 2 further down the page (since block 1 is quite tall compared to block 2.5...

@BWPanda , did you check the z-index? You could use that to overlay blocks or regions and make sure search stays on top.
@Elisabeth Garbeil When I say 'on top' or 'above' I'm thinking in 2D and therefore referring to the y-axis, not the z-axis.

This could have been easily solved with a 2-column layout :sweat_smile: ...but I understand that blocks need to wrap differently on mobile, so understand why you have them in one single region. ...would be great if we had layout variations based on breakpoints.
@BWPanda doesn't adapting grid-row-start and grid-row-end fix it for you?

The first row is as tall as the slideshow block, so you can't have two blocks in the same grid cell (search block is already there). What I might try is playing around with making the slideshow block span multiple rows...
Ah, now I get it. You might need a more complex grid. Spanning the slideshow over two rows might work, too.

klonos said:

This could have been easily solved with a 2-column layout :sweat_smile: ...but I understand that blocks need to wrap differently on mobile, so understand why you have them in one single region. ...would be great if we had layout variations based on breakpoints.

@klonos , That's actually pretty easy to do in CSS using viewport and @media. I think I have 2 or 4 depending on how complex the site is. If you wanted to create a custom theme that did so, you could, if you were concerned about how other people would use it. I think there are a couple of Drupal themes that do that already, like Mix and Match, which is a sub theme of Adaptive. Or you could port Adaptive? Lots of ways to do it, and people will still have to customize :-).

Got it working by telling certain blocks to span multiple rows: image.png
Thanks all!
